verb.description: Persuade (someone) to act in one's favor, typically illegally or dishonestly, by a gift of money or other inducement.
examples: an undercover agent bribed the judge into giving a lenient sentence
you weren't willing to be good to your sister without being bribed with a lollipop
he has no money to bribe with

noun.description: A sum of money or other inducement offered or given to bribe someone.
examples: lawmakers were caught accepting bribes to bring in legalized gambling

origin: Late Middle English: from Old French briber, brimber beg, of unknown origin. The original sense was rob, extort, hence (as a noun) theft, stolen goods, also money extorted or demanded for favors, later offer money as an inducement (early 16th century).
